questiontext.text:
Construct a probability distribution. You may use decimals or fractions for the probabilities.

The probability that a college bookstore sells 0, 1, 2, or 3 statistical calculators on any given day is \( \dfrac49, \dfrac29, \dfrac29, \) and \( dfrac19 \) respectively.

responsetemplate.text: Probability Distribution for p. 264 #19

questiontext.text:
Construct a probability distribution. You may use decimals or fractions for the probabilities.

The probabilities of a return on an investment of $5000, $7000, and $9000 are \( \dfrac12, \dfrac38, \) and \( \dfrac18 \) respectively.

responsetemplate.text: Probability Distribution for p. 264 #20

questiontext.text:
Construct a probability distribution. You can use decimals or fractions for the probabilities.

The probability that an automobile repair shop sells 0, 1, 2, 3, or 4 tires on any given day is 0.25, 0.05, 0.30, 0.00, and 0.40 respectively.

responsetemplate.text: Probability Distribution for p. 264 #21

questiontext.text:
Construct a probability distribution. You can use decimals or fractions for the probabilities.

The probabilities that a customer will rent 0, 1, 2, 3, or 4 DVDs on a single visit to the rental store are 0.15, 0.25, 0.3, 0.25, and 0.05 respectively.

responsetemplate.text: Probability Distribution for p. 264 #22

questiontext.text:
Construct a probability distribution. You can use decimals or fractions for the probabilities.

A die is loaded in such a way that the probabilities of getting 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 are \( \dfrac12, \dfrac16, \dfrac{1}{12}, \dfrac{1}{12}, \dfrac{1}{12} \) and \( \dfrac{1}{12} \) respectively.

responsetemplate.text: Probability Distribution for p. 264 #23

questiontext.text:
Construct a probability distribution. You can use decimals or fractions for the probabilities.

The probabilities that a customer selects 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 items at a convenience store are 0.32, 0.12, 0.23, 0.18, and 0.15, respectively.

responsetemplate.text: Probability Distribution for p. 264 #24

questiontext.text:
Construct a probability distribution. You can use decimals or fractions for the probabilities.

The probabilities that a student is registered for 2, 3, 4, or 5 classes are 0.01, 0.34, 0.62, and 0.03, respectively.

Construct a probability distribution. You can use decimals or fractions for the probabilities.

The probabilities that a randomly selected home has garage space for 0, 1, 2, or 3 cars are 0.22, 0.33, 0.37, and 0.08, respectively.

responsetemplate.text: Probability Distribution for p. 264 #26

questiontext.text: Which of the requirements for a valid probability distribution does the distribution below fail to meet?

answer.text: \( \sum P(X) = 1 \)
\( 0 \leq P(X) \leq 1 \) for all \( X \)
Neither - this distribution is a probability distribution
Both

questiontext.text: Which of the requirements for a valid probability distribution does the distribution below fail to meet?

answer.text: \( \sum P(X) = 1 \)
\( 0 \leq P(X) \leq 1 \) for all \( X \)
Neither - this distribution is a probability distribution
Both

questiontext.text: A researcher wishes to determine the number of cups of coffee a customer drinks with an evening meal at a restaurant. Find the mean for the distribution below. Round your answer to two decimal places.
The number of suits sold per day at a retail store is shown in the table, with the corresponding probabilities. Find the variance of the distribution. Round your answer to the nearest hundredth.
A survey was taken of the number of daily newspapers a person reads per day. Find the standard deviation of the distribution. Round your answer to the nearest hundredth.
The probabilities that a player will get 5 to 10 questions right on a trivia quiz are shown below. Find the variance for the distribution. Round your answer to the nearest hundredth.

A contractor has four new home plans. Plan 1 is a home with 6 windows. Plan 2 is a home with 7 windows. Plan 3 has eight windows, and Plan 4 has nine windows. The probability distribution for the sale of the homes is shown. Find the mean for the number of windows in the homes that the contractor builds. Round your answer to the nearest hundredth.

The county highway department recorded the following probabilities for the number of accidents per day on a certain freeway for one month. The number of accidents per day and their corresponding probabilities are shown. Find the standard deviation. Round your answer to the nearest hundredth.

If a person rolls doubles when she tosses two dice, she wins $5. For the game to be fair, how much should she pay to play the game? Round your answer to the nearest cent.

HINT: A game is fair if \( E(X) = 0 \).

A person pays $2 to play a certain game by rolling a single die once. If a 1 or a 2 comes up, the person wins nothing. If, however, the player rolls a 3, 4, 5, or 6, he or she wins the difference between the number rolled and $2. Find the expectation for this game. Round your answer to the nearest cent.

IMPORTANT NOTE: If a player "wins" a certain amount, this is NOT in addition to what they paid in. For example, if the player rolls a 3, he/she actually loses $1 because the cost was $2 and the winnings were only $1.

A lottery offers one $1000 prize, one $500 prize, and five $100 prizes. One thousand tickets are sold at $3 each. Find the expectation if a person buys one ticket. Round your answer to the nearest cent.
